0.content:
A combination computer and projector dominates the East wall of the garage. The route planner is used by The Driver to scan and plan routes between junctions in a projected map of the Olympic Exclusion Zone.
While using the Route Planner or when accessing the route map, known (scanned) information about Junctions are displayed.
Biome: The junction's biome is displayed in text. (DAMP FOREST)
Map Name: The junction's map name is displayed in text. (TOWN CENTER)
Atmospheric Shifts: This metric shows the relative frequency for Atmospheric Storms to spawn in the junction. A higher value will result in more frequent storms.
Anomaly Density: This metric shows the relative frequency for Anomalies to spawn in the junction.
Zone Storm: This metric shows the speed at which the Instability Storm will collapse on the junction, once it is called. A higher metric value corresponds to a faster storm.
Hazards and Resources: The planner prioritizes displaying: anchors, then Hazards, then all other resources. Not all resources have representation in the route planner.

1.content: The Sealing Kit is primarily used to seal off breaches in the vehicle, preventing harmful substances or environmental anomalies from infiltrating the cabin. In the game, the environment is fraught with dangerous conditions, such as acidic storms, toxic gases, and other threats that can damage the vehicle or impair the player's health. The Sealing Kit is essential for repairing and fortifying the vehicle to ensure it remains functional and safe.

2.content: The Frequency Analyzer and X-tractor (FAX) Machine is an unlimited, dedicated storage location for the collectible documents and audio logs found throughout the Zone.

3.content: The Impact Hammer is essential for interacting with objects that contain useful resources. By using the hammer on specific objects, players can obtain key materials to upgrade their gear and vehicle. The tool serves as a means of breaking down items to collect resources like glass shards, plasma, and copper wire. These materials are indispensable for progressing through the game and enhancing the playerâ€™s tools and vehicle capabilities.

4.content: "No no no, don't tell me, we found a Remnant and its a car this time?!" The Station Wagon is the vehicle used to transport the Driver. The car is customizable with parts and resources found in the Olympic Exclusion Zone. It is also a living anomaly, a Remnant to be precise. It can occasionally suffer from quirks that can do things from opening your door and refuse to close it or throw out a tire. The vehicle was manufactured by Radius Motors with the year model and name as "1983 Station Wagon". Certain parts of the station wagon have strange pulsing veins on it, very similar to the ones covering small structures the player may come across in the Zones. These are most notable under the hood if the engine is removed and with the trunk gunk that holds a small gas can in place. The license plate "MELIC HT" is an anagram of "LIM TECH". The car appears to be based on various different 1980s 'woodie' station wagons, such as the Mercury Colony Park, Dodge Aspen, Chevrolet Malibu and Buick Estate, with the interior in particular resembling a 1980s Mercury Zephyr.

5.content: The Fabrication Station (or "Fabristation") is an interactive computer terminal and attached pneumatic tubing in the far corner of the garage backrooms. It allows The Driver to purchase item blueprints and car and garage upgrades in exchange for Anchor Energy and some incidental raw materials. Purchased blueprints and upgrades are deposited immediately next to the terminal via pneumatic tube.

6.content: Oppy has modified a jukebox in the South-Eastern corner of the garage to receive radio stations. The Driver can interact with the Jukebox in the same ways as with the radio in the station wagon to change the game's soundtrack. Changing the station (track) or volume of the Jukebox immediately affects the same change on the station wagon's radio, and vice-versa. Throwing items at the jukebox will make it turn on.

7.content: Along the shop's wall in the garage's back yard is a Friendly Dumpster - similar to those found throughout the Zone. When used by The Driver, the dumpster will disgorge a pseudo-random selection of useful items. As with other Friendly Dumpsters, it normally refuses to provide more items after it has been activated twice. After each trip into the Zone, the dumpster regains its will to help and may be activated again. If you're ever in dire need, pay this a visit. As much as the Zone takes away, sometimes she also provides. When interacted with, it will spit out various items depending on the players current needs.

8.content: This beauty won't just be your tour guide. It's your north star, and the only way back to safety. Heck, you should consider it the Father, Son, and holy Spirit if you plan on staying alive. That's how important this thing will be to you. Riding shotgun with you is perhaps the most ramshackle and yet remarkable example of technology you've ever seen. It can monitor the Zone, ingest Anchor energy, and casually teleport the entire car and all of it's contents a short distance. It may be a work of a genius, it may be extremely illegal stolen technology, or it may very well be both.

9.content: The way home? This is the way out and you should be double-timing it here, rather than spending your last few seconds scanning things...

10.content: A set of shop benches in the center of the garage area provide The Driver with a place to craft tier 2 components. The workbench's logbook entry implies that it was installed by Oppy in 1971.

11.content: A vertical equipment stack is located in the middle of the shop area, adjacent to the vehicle service area and next to the Charging Station. This Tinker Station can be used by The Driver to diagnose and fix accumulated Quirks with the Station Wagon.

12.content: Purchasing the Scanning Antenna upgrade allows The Driver to install an antenna structure on the roof of the auto parts building. With this antenna installed, the Route Planner gains the ability to scan and plan routes to junctions beyond just E5. Purchasing the Improved Antenna upgrade increases the number of junction scans the route planner can make before a trip.
